awd_titl_txt: SCH: EXP: From Critique to Collaboration: A Fundamental Rethinking of Computerized Clinical Alerts
awd_abstract_narration:
To prescribe safe medications, physicians use computerized physician order entry (CPOE) that routinely relies on drug-drug interaction (DDI) alerts. Despite the current attempts to reduce frequency and complexity of alerts, the effectiveness of such alerts remains extremely low, with up to 96% of warnings being ignored by physicians on a daily basis. The primary cause for this is alert fatigue, a state in which physicians, bombarded by numerous warnings, become desensitized. The goal of this project is to transform drug safety alerts from oft-ignored warnings to trusted tools that advise physicians in daily decision making. To accomplish this, the investigators are aiming beyond incremental improvement  establishing novel principles for alert design that are based on what physicians consider important when taking advice from peers in their daily clinical work.  The project is addressing this problem with a three prong approach:  (1) determining principles that accompany trusted physician-to-physician advice regarding appropriate medication prescribing; formative studies will be conducted in a variety of clinical settings to identify key factors in sharing trusted advice among doctors and residents; (2) generating novel designs for drug safety guidance that elicit physician trust and maximize compliance and (3) evaluating the impact of novel designs on physician compliance to DDI warnings.

Intellectual Merit:
By investigating the question of why physicians trust each other, the project is leveraging a fundamental behavioral dynamics reconsidering the role of clinical alerts, and thus generating new principles to design effective computerized guidance that elicits similar notions of trust. A very important contribution of this research is a more complete understanding of what makes physician-to-physician advice trustworthy in the ecosystem of daily clinical activities provides a solid, long-term intellectual basis for the creation of substantially better alerts for a broad variety of CPOE systems. Key innovative aspect of  this work is the departure from the mere optimization of alerts to focus rather on complex yet crucial dynamics by which trusted advice is shared among physicians. There are potentially transformative aspects of the proposed work, which if successful, could unleash a new generation of drug-drug interaction warnings that will substantially advance the level of adherence in daily medication prescribing.

Broader Impacts:
The outcomes from this project will potentially affect the over 600,000 physicians in the United States who spend the majority of their time in direct patient care, and who are exposed to dozens of DDI alerts on a daily basis. By reframing current alerting strategies, the project results are expected to substantially increase safe drug prescription in day-to-day clinical setting.  The investigators are disseminating the project results through large-scale real-world CPOE deployments and live experimental evaluations available to hundreds of physicians. The team is also reaching out to CPOE vendors, to promote the incorporation of the ideas generated in the project in the current and next generation of products. Ultimately, this basic research in physician communication and human-computer interaction is providing the research basis to catalyze a change in industry practice, also facilitated by the PI's leadership of the EMR Innovations Summit, an annual meeting of national EMR vendors hosted by the Regenstrief Institute.

por.por_cntn:
The safe prescribing of patient medications via computerized physician order entry (CPOE) routinely relies on drug safety alerts. The most common type of such alerts, drug-drug interaction (DDI) warnings, are a basic form of clinical decision support, but their effectiveness remains surprisingly low: up to 96% of such warnings are ignored by physicians on a daily basis. Non-compliance to DDI leads to increased risk of prescribing unsafe medications, which may cause serious health complications and even death. Numerous strategies have attempted to reduce alert fatigue, from decreasing the intrusiveness of alerts to simplifying their visual design to improving the specificity of the underlying data. Still, physician adherence remains low, as does satisfaction and trust in clinical alerting systems.

In this project, we explored critical social, communication and cognitive factors that inform a fundamental rethinking of effective DDI alerts for physicians. Specifically, we proposed a different perspective to advance the interaction science on DDI alerts: before re-designing alerts, we need to focus on improving the trust between physicians and computerized advice by examining why physicians trust their medical colleagues. Based on this fundamental behavioral dynamics, we envisioned and demonstrated a new family of trust-based alerts that have the potential to elicit more trust and reflection among users.

The results of this project are significant. In a refereed paper accepted at the ACM CHI conference?s Late-Breaking Work category, we introduced a model to guide the design of trust-based clinical alerts?based on what physicians value when trusting advice from peers in clinical activities. We examine three key dimensions to craft trusted alerts: (1) using colleagues? endorsement; (2) foregrounding physicians? prior actions, and (3) adopting a suitable language. We then exemplified our approach with emerging alert designs from our ongoing research with physicians and contribute to the current debate on how to design effective alerts to improve patient safety. Our paper won a Best Paper Honorable Mention, a prestigious recognition bestowed on only 5% of all Late-Breaking Work submissions.

In our follow-up field study, published in the Interacting with Computers journal, we empirically investigated key elements of trusted advice among physicians. To this end, we conducted three contextual inquiries in a hospital setting (22 physicians), and corroborated our findings with a survey (37 physicians) that identified drivers that guide physicians in trusting peer advice. These include: timeliness of the advice, collaborative language, empathy, level of specialization and responsiveness to the medical hierarchy. Based on these findings, we introduce seven design directions for trust-based alerts: endorsement, transparency, team sensing, collaborative, empathic, conflict mitigating and agency laden designs. Our work contributes to novel alert design strategies to improve the effectiveness of drug safety advice.

Based on these results, we conducted a mixed-method sequential study, also published in Interacting with Computers, in which we designed, developed and evaluated 11 novel types of DDI alerts embodying different trust?eliciting cues. Trust cues included expert endorsements (Chief of Quality, Institute of Medicine, Literature), Institutional History, physician?s history, collaboration cues, and increased transparency. Our findings suggest that: (i) endorsed messages drive trust but only if accompanied with data summaries, otherwise evoking condescension among physicians; (ii) situated awareness of adverse events (in the hospital or among prior patients) promotes reflection and triggers further monitoring, critical for patient safety; and (iii) future trust-based alerts should provide richer, alternative recommendations and link explanatory data resources beyond simple warnings and directives. The NSF has featured the results of our project on NSF Discovery, in occasion of National Safety Month , and I have given three national presentations to all other PIs funded by the NSF Smart and Connected health Program.

These encouraging results have opened new opportunities to expand HCI research into deepening the role of trust cues in clinical alerts and to pursue larger NSF grant opportunities in the Smart and Connected Health Program.
